instruction: Create a template in markdown to create scope for Jira tickets. Members should use this template as a checklist to ensure they have included all the necessary information when creating a ticket.
output:
Sure! Here's a template in Markdown that you can use to create a scope for Jira tickets:

**Jira Ticket Scope Template**
=================================

Please use this template as a checklist to ensure that you have included all the necessary information when creating a Jira ticket.

### 1. Summary

* Provide a brief summary of the issue or feature request.

### 2. Description

* Provide a detailed description of the issue or feature request, including any relevant background information or context.

### 3. Requirements

* Clearly outline the requirements for the issue or feature request, including any specific functionality or features that are needed.

### 4. Impact

* Describe the impact of the issue or feature request on the project, including any potential risks or benefits.

### 5. Priority

* Assign a priority level to the issue or feature request, based on the project's priorities and the needs of the stakeholders.

### 6. Acceptance Criteria

* Outline the acceptance criteria for the issue or feature request, including any specific metrics or benchmarks that must be met.

### 7. Dependencies

* Identify any dependencies or prerequisites for the issue or feature request, including any other tickets or tasks that must be completed first.

### 8. Estimation

* Estimate the time and resources required to complete the issue or feature request, including any potential roadblocks or challenges.

### 9. Stakeholders

* Identify all stakeholders who are impacted by the issue or feature request, including any end-users, developers, or other team members.

### 10. Additional Information

* Provide any additional information that may be relevant to the issue or feature request, such as screenshots, diagrams, or links to related tickets.

By using this template as a checklist, you can ensure that you have included all the necessary information when creating a Jira ticket, and that your ticket is well-organized and easy to understand.

instruction:
As part of software engineering, user stories describe what the user wants the system to do, while acceptance criteria describe the conditions a specific user story must meet. Create basic acceptance criteria based on the given user story.

User story: As a user, I want to use a search field to type a city, name, or street, so that I could find matching hotel options.
output:
Sure! Here are some basic acceptance criteria based on the given user story:

1. The search field should be prominently displayed on the hotel booking page.
2. The search field should accept input in the form of a city, name, or street.
3. The search field should return a list of matching hotel options as the user types.
4. The list of matching hotel options should be displayed in real-time, as the user types.
5. The list of matching hotel options should include the hotel name, location, and a brief description.
6. The user should be able to select a hotel from the list of matching hotel options.
7. The system should display the selected hotel's details, including price, availability, and booking options.
8. The system should allow the user to clear the search field and start a new search.

These acceptance criteria cover the basic functionality of a search field that allows users to find matching hotel options based on city, name, or street. Of course, depending on the specific requirements of the system, additional acceptance criteria may be necessary.

instruction:
A user story is an informal, general explanation of a software feature written from the perspective of the end user or customer. Write a user story for a given software.

Gmail
output:
Sure! Here's a user story for Gmail:

Title: As a busy professional, I want to be able to quickly and easily organize my emails so that I can focus on what's important and avoid feeling overwhelmed.

Description: As a Gmail user, I want to be able to label and categorize my emails in a way that makes sense to me, so that I can quickly find important messages and ignore less important ones. I also want to be able to set up filters to automatically sort and prioritize my emails, so that I can focus on what's important and avoid feeling overwhelmed.

Acceptance Criteria:

* The user should be able to create labels and categories for their emails.
* The user should be able to apply labels and categories to individual emails or batches of emails.
* The user should be able to set up filters to automatically sort and prioritize their emails based on specific criteria (e.g. subject line, sender, etc.).
* The user should be able to view their emails in a list or in a grid, with the ability to sort and filter the list based on the labels and categories they have created.
* The user should be able to quickly and easily search for specific emails by keyword, label, or category.

Benefits:

* The user will be able to quickly and easily organize their emails, reducing the time and effort spent searching for important messages.
* The user will be able to focus on what's important and avoid feeling overwhelmed by a cluttered inbox.
* The user will be able to set up filters to automatically sort and prioritize their emails, reducing the time and effort spent on manual sorting and prioritization.

Title: New Employee Onboarding Process Improvement

Project: HR Operations

Priority: High

Estimation: 2 weeks

As part of our ongoing efforts to improve the new employee onboarding process, we are looking to streamline and enhance the experience for all new hires. The goal of this project is to create a seamless and efficient onboarding process that sets our new employees up for success from day one.

2. The new process is implemented and monitored for effectiveness
3. Feedback from new hires and managers is gathered and used to make adjustments to the process
4. Metrics such as time to complete onboarding, employee satisfaction, and retention rates show improvement

Notes:

* This project will be completed in two weeks, with the following milestones:
	+ Week 1: Review current onboarding process and identify areas for improvement
	+ Week 2: Develop and implement the revised onboarding process
* The HR Operations team will be responsible for completing this project, with support from the management team and other stakeholders as needed.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions or need further clarification.

instruction:
Make a list of the pros and cons of the given decision.

Implementing a Remote Working Policy
output:
Sure, here's a list of pros and cons of implementing a remote working policy:

Pros:

1. Increased flexibility and work-life balance for employees: With remote working, employees can work from anywhere, at any time, as long as they have a stable internet connection. This can lead to a better work-life balance and more flexibility in managing personal and professional responsibilities.
2. Reduced commuting time and expenses: By not having to commute to an office, employees can save time and money that would have been spent on transportation.
3. Access to a wider talent pool: With remote working, the company can attract and hire the best talent from all over the world, without being limited by geographical location.
4. Improved productivity and efficiency: Some employees may find that they are more productive when working remotely, as they are able to avoid office distractions and work in a setting that is more conducive to their needs.
5. Cost savings: By not having to maintain a physical office space, the company can save on rent, utilities, and other overhead costs.
6. Environmental benefits: Reducing the need for commuting can lead to a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and other negative environmental impacts.

Cons:

1. Lack of face-to-face interaction: Remote working can lead to a lack of face-to-face interaction among employees, which can negatively impact team collaboration and communication.
2. Difficulty in building a company culture: Without the benefit of face-to-face interaction, it can be challenging for the company to build a strong culture and sense of community among employees.
3. Difficulty in setting boundaries: With remote working, it can be challenging for employees to disconnect from work and maintain a healthy work-life balance.
4. Technical challenges: Remote working can be impacted by issues such as internet connectivity and software compatibility, which can hinder productivity and collaboration.
5. Security concerns: With remote working, there is a higher risk of data breaches and cybersecurity threats, as employees may be using their own devices and networks to access company data.
6. Difficulty in providing support: Without the benefit of face-to-face interaction, it can be more challenging for the company to provide support and resources to remote employees.
7. Potential for isolation: Remote working can lead to feelings of isolation among employees, which can negatively impact their mental health and well-being.
8. Difficulty in building trust: Without the benefit of face-to-face interaction, it can be challenging for the company to build trust with remote employees.

Overall, the decision to implement a remote working policy should be carefully considered, taking into account the potential pros and cons, as well as the needs and preferences of the company and its employees.

instruction:
Include important study notes and key points that someone should know about the given subject.

history of the USA
output:
Sure, here are some important study notes and key points about the history of the United States of America:

1. Pre-Columbian Era (before 1492):
	* Indigenous peoples inhabited the Americas for thousands of years, with diverse cultures and civilizations.
	* Major pre-Columbian civilizations include the Mayans, Aztecs, and Incas.
2. European Exploration and Colonization (1492-1776):
	* European explorers, led by Christopher Columbus, arrived in the Americas in 1492.
	* The Spanish, British, French, and Dutch established colonies in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean.
	* The colonies developed differently, with the Southern colonies focused on agriculture (tobacco, cotton, and sugar) and the New England colonies focused on trade and industry.
3. American Revolution and Early National Period (1776-1828):
	* The American Revolution (1775-1783) resulted in the independence of the colonies from Great Britain.
	* The Early National Period saw the establishment of the new government under the Articles of Confederation and the drafting of the United States Constitution.
	* The Constitution created a federal system with three branches of government and established principles such as federalism and individual rights.
4. Westward Expansion and Manifest Destiny (1803-1860):
	* The Louisiana Purchase of 1803 and the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848 expanded U.S. territory westward, resulting in a significant increase in the size of the country.
	* The concept of Manifest Destiny, which held that the United States was destined to expand its territory and spread its political and cultural influence, drove westward expansion.
5. Civil War and Reconstruction (1861-1877):
	* The Civil War (1861-1865) was fought between the Union (the Northern states) and the Confederacy (the Southern states) over issues such as slavery, states' rights, and economic and cultural differences.
	* The Reconstruction period that followed saw the abolition of slavery, the passage of civil rights legislation, and the reintegration of the South into the Union.
6. Industrialization and Immigration (1870-1914):
	* The late 19th and early 20th centuries saw significant industrialization and immigration to the United States, with the growth of cities and the development of new technologies.
	* Immigrants from Europe and other parts of the world came to the United States seeking economic opportunities and political freedom.
7. World War I and the Roaring Twenties (1914-1929):
	* The United States entered World War I in 1917 and emerged from the war as a major world power.
	* The 1920s were marked by a period of economic prosperity and cultural change, with the rise of consumer culture, jazz music, and the Harlem Renaissance.
8. The Great Depression and World War II (1929-1945):
	* The stock market crash of 1929 led to the Great Depression, a period of economic hardship that lasted over a decade.
	* The United States' entry into World War II in 1941 marked a turning point in the global conflict and cemented the country's status as a superpower.
9. Cold War and Civil Rights Era (1945-1989):
	* The period following World War II saw the beginning of the Cold War between the United States and the Soviet Union, with the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan aiming to contain communism and rebuild Europe.
	* The Civil Rights Movement of the 1950s and 1960s sought to end racial segregation and discrimination in the United States, with landmark legislation such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
10. Contemporary Era (1990-present):
	* The end of the Cold War marked a period of globalization and the rise of the United States as the sole superpower.
	* Contemporary issues such as terrorism, immigration, and economic inequality continue to shape the United States and its role in the world.

Some key points to keep in mind when studying the history of the United States include:

* The United States has a diverse history, with the experiences of different groups such as indigenous peoples, African Americans, women, and immigrants shaping the country's development.
* The United States has been shaped by both domestic and international events, with global conflicts and economic trends influencing the country's history.
* The United States has a complex system of government, with checks and balances and a system of federalism that has evolved over time.
* The United States has a strong tradition of individual rights and freedoms, with the Constitution and Bill of Rights protecting the rights of citizens.

I hope these study notes and key points are helpful in your exploration of the history of the United States!

```
for i in range(10):

    print(i)
```

```
for i in range(10):
```

```
1

```

instruction: For a quick and efficient office workout, suggest a short routine.
output:
Sure, here's a quick and efficient office workout routine that you can do in just 10 minutes:

1. Desk push-ups: Place your hands on your desk and do push-ups, keeping your body in a straight line from head to heels. Do 10-15 reps.
2. Chair squats: Stand up and sit down in your chair without using your hands. Do 10-15 reps.
3. Wall sit: Stand with your back against the wall and slide down into a seated position, keeping your knees bent at a 90-degree angle. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute.
4. Leg raises: Sit in your chair and lift one leg off the floor, keeping it bent at a 90-degree angle. Hold for a few seconds and then lower it back down. Do 10-15 reps on each leg.
5. Arm circles: Hold your arms straight out to the sides and make small circles with your hands. Do 5-10 reps in each direction (forward and backward).
6. Desk dips: Place your hands on the edge of your desk and lower your body down by bending your elbows, keeping your legs straight. Do 10-15 reps.
7. Shoulder rolls: Roll your shoulders forward and backward in a circular motion. Do 5-10 reps.
8. Wrist circles: Hold your arms straight out in front of you and make small circles with your wrists. Do 5-10 reps in each direction (forward and backward).
9. Seated march: Sit in your chair and march in place, keeping your legs bent at a 90-degree angle. Do 30 seconds to 1 minute.
10. Plank: Start in a push-up position, but instead of lowering your body down, hold yourself up in a straight line from head to heels. Hold for 30 seconds to 1 minute.

Remember to stretch before and after your workout, and to listen to your body and take breaks as needed. This routine is designed to be quick and efficient, but it's important to pace yourself and not push yourself too hard.

instruction:
Using the ingredients that are available, create a dinner recipe.

Kale + almond butter + apple cider vinegar + agave nectar + tamari
output:
Sure! Here's a dinner recipe using the ingredients you provided:

Kale and Almond Butter Stir-Fry with Apple Cider Vinegar and Agave Nectar Glaze

Ingredients:

* 2 cups kale, chopped
* 1/4 cup almond butter
* 2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar
* 1 tablespoon agave nectar
* 1 tablespoon tamari
* 1 tablespoon olive oil
* Salt and pepper, to taste

Instructions:

1. Heat the olive oil in a large skillet or wok over medium-high heat.
2. Add the chopped kale to the skillet and cook for 2-3 minutes, or until the kale is slightly wilted.
3. In a small bowl, whisk together the almond butter, apple cider vinegar, agave nectar, and tamari.
4. Pour the glaze over the kale and toss to coat.
5. Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes, or until the kale is tender and the glaze is caramelized.
6. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
7. Serve hot and enjoy!

This recipe is a delicious and healthy way to incorporate the ingredients you provided into your dinner. The kale provides a boost of vitamins and antioxidants, while the almond butter adds healthy fats and protein. The apple cider vinegar and agave nectar add a tangy and slightly sweet glaze, while the tamari provides a savory and umami flavor. This dish is perfect for a weeknight dinner or as a side dish for a special occasion. Enjoy!

instruction:
Provide instructions for the given exercise.

Leg Raises
output:
Sure! Here are the instructions for the leg raise exercise:

1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and your feet flat on the floor. Your arms should be at your sides, with your palms facing down.
2. Engage your core muscles by drawing your belly button towards your spine.
3. Slowly lift one leg off the ground, keeping it straight.
4. Hold the lifted position for 2-3 seconds.
5. Slowly lower your leg back down to the starting position.
6. Repeat the exercise with the other leg.
7. Perform 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions on each leg.

Here are some tips to help you perform the leg raise exercise correctly:

* Keep your core muscles engaged throughout the exercise.
* Use slow and controlled movements.
* Avoid arching your back or using momentum to lift your legs.
* Keep your legs straight and your feet flat on the floor.
* Breathe naturally and avoid holding your breath.

Remember to focus on proper form and technique, and gradually increase the number of repetitions as you build strength and endurance. It's also important to listen to your body and take breaks as needed. If you experience any discomfort or pain, stop the exercise and consult with a healthcare professional.

Challenge Name: "Spring into Fitness"

Objective: To encourage Strava users to get outside and be active during the spring season.

Challenge Description:

Spring is here, and it's the perfect time to get outside and get moving! For the next 4 weeks, we challenge you to complete at least 10 minutes of outdoor activity per day. This can be anything from a walk, run, bike ride, or swim. The goal is to get moving and enjoy the beautiful spring weather.

Challenge Details:

* Duration: 4 weeks
* Start date: March 20th
* End date: April 15th
* Minimum daily activity requirement: 10 minutes

To participate, simply log your outdoor activities on Strava during the challenge period. Your activities must be at least 10 minutes long and must be recorded outdoors. You can use any device to track your activities, including a smartphone, GPS watch, or cycling computer.

Challenge Prizes:

* Top finisher: A $100 gift card to a local outdoor gear store
* Top female finisher: A $50 gift card to a local yoga studio
* Top male finisher: A $50 gift card to a local running store
* Random participant prize: A $25 gift card to a local coffee shop

Challenge Hashtags:

#SpringIntoFitness #StravaChallenge #GetOutside

Challenge Leaderboard:

The leaderboard will be based on the total amount of time spent outdoors during the challenge period. Participants can view the leaderboard on the Strava app or website to see how they rank.

Challenge Tips:

* Get creative with your activities! Instead of just going for a run or bike ride, try something new like kayaking, stand-up paddleboarding, or hiking.
* Find a workout buddy to keep you motivated and accountable.
* Use the Strava app to track your activities and earn rewards for completing your daily challenges.
* Share your activities on social media using the challenge hashtags to connect with other participants.

We hope you'll join us for the "Spring into Fitness" challenge and get outside to enjoy the beautiful spring weather!
